meta.text_info: This quick app is an open-source project, powered by open data and enriched by the community.
meta.text_acknowledge: Most of the information was extracted from Wikidata, OpenStreetMaps and public sources. [add your name here :)]
meta.text_feedback: If you have seen any inaccuracy or if you want to contribute with your experience or pictures, please let us know.

pois.name: Pieter Coutereel
pois.description: Pieter Couterel (1320-1373), mayor of Louvain
pois.more: Pieter Couterel (also 'Pe(e)ter' or 'Pierre', surname also 'Cotterel', 'Coutreel', 'Cout(h)ereel' or 'Koutereel'), meier of Louvain from 1348. Although not of nobility or particularly wealthy, he was nevertheless appointed to this high post by Duke John III of Brabant.

pois.name: De Kotmadam
pois.description: Lady running a kot, a typical type of student residence in Leuven
pois.more: The statue, by Fred Bellefroid, was inaugurated on May 16, 1985. It was a gift from the tourist office to the city of Leuven (worth 800,000 Bfr), but an original idea of ​​the Marktrock committee. The inauguration was attended by Maria Swerts, the then oldest Leuven kotmadam and godmother of the statue. Despite the amusing nature of the image, the Kotmadam initially evoked mixed feelings. For example, the figure depicted did not correspond to the typical image of a kotmadam: old and slender. On the contrary, the kotmadam on the Oude Markt is a young, attractive lady.

pois.name: Fonske
pois.description: Het Fonske -Fons Sapientiae, Latin for Source of Wisdom-
pois.more: Het Fonske is one of the works of Jef Claerhout and was donated to the city in 1975 on the occasion of the 550th anniversary of the Catholic University of Leuven.

pois.description: Paep(e) Thoon was a folk figure in Leuven in the Burgundian Netherlands during the Middle Ages.
pois.more: From Leuven in the 15th century, numerous stories circulate about this figure
pois.name: Paepe Thoon
Erasmus
pois.description: Statue by René Rosseel that represents the scholar and humanist Erasmus (1467-1536), lecturer at the University of Leuven

pois.name: Dorre de Bakker
pois.description: Bronze statue by Roland Rens, donated by the Leuven Association of Bread and Pastry Bakers in 1979.

pois.name: Vrijheidsboom
pois.description: Freedom tree planted when the Belgian Revolution started in 1830
pois.more: The Belgian Revolution was the conflict which led to the secession of the southern provinces (former Southern Netherlands) from the United Kingdom of the Netherlands and the establishment of an independent Kingdom of Belgium. Leuven was briefly besieged by the regular Dutch troops on September 23, but with the help of farmers from the area they were driven out.

pois.name: Oer Atoom
pois.description: Artwork across the city center, based on the Georges Lemaître's Big Bang theory.
pois.more: The Primordial Atom, based on the Big Bang theory, written in Leuven by Professor Georges Lemaître. This revolutionary theory was issued in 1931 at the University of Leuven. As a tribute, there is a new city artwork. It is called 'Oer Atom' and it transforms the inner city into a universe. From now on you will find galaxies between the street tiles and 1 meter is equal to 10 million light years. Walk through the city and experience the wonder of the universe with a work of art that only belongs in Leuven.

pois.name: Rembert Dodoens
pois.description: Rembert Dodoens was a Flemish physician and botanist, considered the father of botany
pois.more: Statue in the Botanical Garden remmembering Rembert Dodoens (born Rembert Van Joenckema, 29 June 1517 – 10 March 1585), also known under his Latinized name Rembertus Dodonaeus.

pois.name: Middelpunt der Stad Leuven
pois.description: Center of the City of Leuven, from 1975, when pedestrian Mechelsestraat was opened
pois.more: According to a photo from 1864, the landmark stone used to be located on the Zeven Hoeken (today Mathieu De Layensplein)

pois.name: Sint-Janspomp
pois.description: The Sint-Janspomp, named after Sint-Jansbron that traditionally supplied the neighborhood with drinking water
pois.more: It's dated in 1856 and replaced an older pump from 1702.

pois.name: De Koeieschieter
pois.description: De Koeieschieter, or cow shooter, is one nickname of the people of Leuven
pois.more: A folk tale mentions that during one night in 1691, the people of Leuven saw all kinds of suspicious movements in the dark. They thought they were being attacked by the French, so they opened fire. The next morning it turned out that they had only killed cows. This 'heroic' act earned the Leuven resident the nickname Cow Shooters

pois.name: Ode to friendship
pois.description: Statue built by Dany Tulkens in 1988, as a gift to the city from Verbond der Jaartallen
pois.more: The statue stood on Herbert Hooverplein for almost 30 years

pois.name: Justo Lipsio
pois.description: Justus Lipsius (or Joest Lips) (1547-1606), humanist and Latin Professor at the University of Leuven.
pois.more: He was one of the most famous scholars of the 16 century

pois.name: The Totem
pois.description: The Beetle's Totem, by Jan Fabre
pois.more: Built in 2005 to celebrate the 575th anniversary of KU Leuven. According to the creator, the combination of a surreal installation with the classic university library building reflects the character of the city and its most important university.

pois.description: A sword, flames and coat arms (symbolizing the rebuilt after the Great War)

pois.name: Fiere Margriet
pois.description: Margaret of Louvain (1207–1225) was a servant murdered by thieves
pois.more: As a teenager, she worked at the inn belonging to her relatives, a certain Aubert and his wife, until they sold the establishment. The couple had planned to enter the religious life, with Margaret herself set on joining a Cistercian convent.

pois.name: Vredesmonument
pois.description: (Peace Memorial) Memorial to the First World War victims
pois.more: This obelisk dates from 1925, but was destroyed by the German occupiers during the Second World War in 1940. In 2004, the city of Leuven restored the monument.

pois.name: Jozef De Veuster
pois.description: (Pater Damiaan) (1840-1889), Father of the Congregation of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Maria
pois.more: Damien of Molokai, missionary, become known for his work with leprosy patients. He is the patron saint of lepers and AIDS patients. Statue built in 1894

pois.name: Edouard Remy
pois.description: Socially committed entrepreneur of the 19th century.
pois.more: Remy employed hundreds of people in his rice and starch factory in Wijgmaal (part of Louvain). Sculpture designed by Victor Horta (1861-1947) and built by Pieter Braecke.  Innaugurated in 1899.

pois.name: Renée
pois.description: Renée represents the active female students in Leuven
pois.more: By Armand Loveniers. The sculpture was donated in 1997 by the Merchants Association. The actual initiator was René Depret, honorary citizen of the city of Leuven, which gives its name to the statue.

pois.name: Geluksbrenger
pois.description: The Dijle duck is a lucky charm and helps to make a wish when you drink the water
pois.more: Rub the duck three times on the tail to get water

pois.name: Andre Dumont
pois.description: 1847-1920. Discoverer of coal in Campine in 1901

pois.name: Pieter de Somer
pois.description: (1966-1985) The first Rector of the University, biologist
pois.more: Founder of the Rega Institute

pois.name: Kamerood Sesteg
pois.description: Statue Was donated by the 'Men of 60' to the City of Leuven in 2000
pois.more: By Eremarraine Wendy Van Wanten and Christian Smets

pois.name: Abraham
pois.description: A wise Abraham knows where to look for the mustard (a sign of wisdom)
pois.more: Abraham is how men are called in Leuven after their 50s, and 'knowing where to look for mustard' is a sign of wisdom.

pois.name: Mariabeeld
pois.description: Virgin Mary over the wall of the former Duke of Brabant's castle
pois.more: The old castle wall is of historical importance, because it is the only remnant of the lost castle of the Duke of Brabant. The military checkpoint on Keizersberg was modeled on the castles seen by the Duke on his crusades, and is believed to have been built in the 13th century. The City of Leuven took the Keizersberg park on a long lease in 2011 and opened it up to the public as the green lung of the Vaartkom.

pois.name: Kartuizerpomp
pois.description: Carthusian pump, that originally stood in the Carthusian monastery of Leuven
pois.more: In 1799, the city council had the water pump moved to its current location, in the middle of the city.

pois.name: Kattenpomp
pois.description: Cattenpomp or De Gulden Fonteyne water pump, dated from 1729.
pois.more: On one side of the pump there is a sign with the text: Get two buckets of water, two buckets pumps, the girls with their clogs, the girls from the kattestraat..., which is a variant of the Flemish folk song Get two buckets of water.

pois.name: Hooverplein
pois.description: Water fountain that re-visualize Leuven's historic city walls throughout the city
pois.more: The fountain is shaped like the street plan of Leuven, as Jacob van Deventer, the famous Dutch cartographer, drew it in 1550.

pois.name: Van de Weerstand
pois.description: National monument that commemorates the resistance in Belgium in the Second World War

pois.name: King Albert I
pois.description: King Albert I, supreme commander of the Belgian Army in the First World War.

pois.name: De ontvoering van Europa
pois.description: The Abduction of Europe represents the god Zeus (as a bull), who kidnaps Europa
pois.more: This is a famous scene from Greek mythology that was also immortalized on canvas by Rubens and Moreau. It was made by the sculptor Rik Poot.

pois.name: Sint-Jacobspomp
pois.description: Public pump
pois.more: 18th century public pump, placed in the Sint-Hubertusstraat, near the Sint-Jacobsmarkt and the Sint-Jacobskerk (church). It has two pump iron arms. At the top there is a niche, in which there used to be a statue of Saint James. A lantern hangs in front of the niche. The pump has been a protected heritage site since 1995.
